We use the R dataset `HairEyeColor` as an example which records the hair and eye colour from a survey of 592 students at the University of Delaware^[It also records "Sex" but this value is fake.]. 
  
```{r}
knitr::kable(apply(HairEyeColor, 1:2, sum))
```

  
We have to choose which of these two variates should be the response, which is the conditioning variate. That is, an eikosogram has an explicit model in mind when it is constructed.
It assumes interest lies in
$$Pr(Y = y | X = x)$$
where Y is the "response" and "X" is the "conditioning" variate^[eikos always takes a response variate and one (or more) conditioning variates.].    
  
If we take "Hair" to be the response, we would call the eikos function with conditioning variate
"Eye" as follows:  
```{r, message=FALSE, fig.width=4, fig.height=3}
library(eikos)
eikos("Hair", "Eye", data = HairEyeColor, xaxs=FALSE, yaxs=FALSE)
```

Interchanging the two variates gives "Eye" as the response and "Hair" as the conditioning variate:
```{r, message=FALSE, warning=FALSE, fig.width=4, fig.height=3}
eikos("Eye", "Hair", data=HairEyeColor, xaxs=FALSE, yaxs=FALSE)
```

We could also write the variates as a formula:  
```{r, fig.width=4, fig.height=3}
eikos(Eye~Hair, data=HairEyeColor)
```

We could add the values of the proportions on the axes by setting xaxs=TRUE, yaxs=TRUE:
```{r, message=FALSE, warning=FALSE, fig.width=4, fig.height=3}
eikos("Eye", "Hair", data = HairEyeColor, xaxs=TRUE, yaxs=TRUE)
```
